Funnily enough, mages arent "so much better" than traditional supports for the most part. In fact, I'd say that most of the time they are worse. The thing is, mage-supports have potential to carry, even though its difficult to snowball hard enough to do so. For that fact alone, people are willing to take the high-risk, high-reward option because it puts the win condition in their hands instead of relying too hard on your team. 

But actually look at the winrates. The Sion support is an anomoly, but after that the current list goes: Sona, Janna, Blitz, Soraka, Taric, Lulu, Leona. In fact, Janna is probably the most consistent - always at around a 52-53% winrate, almost always within the top-4 supports you can pick. People just dont like playing her since youre basically an add-on champion - you dont really do anything for yourself, but you make your ADC twice as strong. With a good ADC, it works, but making a bad ADC twice as strong doesnt give you much influence in the game.

I've 100-0'ed, solo killed, an enemy ADC before, as support Nami. This is something mage supports do, and I did it on a traditional support. While still being effective in healing my allies, having Sightstone and Redemption, and pursuing objectives, and gaining little CS. So, just because mage supports do more damage, it does not mean they are _better_.
It is always so frightening to see a death recap to see a bubble do like 300 or so damage without ap, (talking early anyway)

ADCs are used to play balls-out when they have whole team peeling for them, which is nice, but they can't do that when there are more important champions on their team.
They refuse to adapt to changing enviroment, and they feel entitled to get protected. 
When top laner picks Quinn or Vayne, they never ask for peel or protection, they are used to playing safely and peeling for themselves. But bot lane ADC always rages and flames if he doesn't get peel he's used to. It's more of a psychological issue than anything else.
